Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
November 17, 2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Two out of eight foster care records reviewed contained late
physical examinations and was not completed. One physical
examination was due by 5/13/21 and another by 6/12/21.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Three out of eight foster care records reviewed contained late
updated service plans. One service plan was late by 6 days,
second report was late by 2 days and the third service plan was
late by 1 day.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS (Commitment 22)
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated
Child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will
be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal
reporting requirements.
In several of eight open foster child records, various records did
4

Not show consistent uploads of all signed and timely
documentation such as parent agency treatment plans, updated
medical passports, USP’s and FTM’s.
ISEP 6.30 Supervisory oversight (Commitment 66)
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on
the worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and
approve each service plan. The plan can be approved only
after the supervisor has a face-to-face meeting with the
worker, which can be the monthly meeting.
One out of eight foster care records, one did not have
supervision between the worker and supervisor documented
monthly/prior to signing a USP.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Personnel Training
SRM 200
All personnel, contractors, vendors and external auditors
who have access to CW-CHRI are required to complete
security awareness training (SAT). Training will be
available on the Learning Management System (LMS) per
MDHHS personnel and contractors with access to this
system.
SAT is required to be taken within six months of being in a
position with CW - CHRI access and every two years
thereafter. CPA’s are responsible for ensuring that all
personnel with CHRI access completes the SAT. DCWL
consultant will monitor completion of SAT in all CPA’s as
part of the annual audit.
Since the last inspection there were ten employees with
access to criminal record history information (CHRI). Based
on a review of LMS transcript for employees, three employees
was found to have not completed SAT timely. These employees
need to complete SAT training as soon as possible to retain
5

access to CHRI records and complete their job duties as
licensing, adoption, and/supervision staff.
DHHS Family Team Meeting
Policy722-06B
Family Team Meeting Type Time Frame
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
One out of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain an
FTM for the 12/20/21 – 7/16/21 report period.

DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver and Birth Parent

The foster parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP
process. The foster parent/caregiver signature is required
and indicates that the foster parent/caregiver
acknowledges and agrees to the activities required to meet
the needs of the child in their care.
Signatures must be documented within 30 days.
Two out of eight foster care records did not have documentation
of a PATP signed by the caregiver. These reports was for
reports 6/30/21 -9/27/21 and 5/30/21 – 8/27/21.

DHHS Policy Medical Passport
FOM 801 – page
14-15
All medical information required by policy and/or law must
be provided to the foster parent. This includes copies of
the medical and dental examinations (if available) and the
information required in the medical passport. For children
first entering foster care, the initial medical passport must
be provided to the caregivers within two weeks of the
child's placement date. The actual date the caregivers
receive the medical passport must be documented in
MiSACWIS. All medical information within the medical
passport must be current and updated at least quarterly to
6

reflect the child's current and complete health information.
Placement agency foster care (PAFC) providers must
provide a copy of the medical passport to MDHHS
monitoring staff as it is updated but no less often than
annually. Each foster care worker who transfers a child's
medical passport to another foster care worker must sign
and date the medical passport verifying that s/he has
sought and obtained the necessary information under law
and MDHHS policy. An updated medical passport is
provided to: Legal parents if the child is a temporary court
ward. All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is referred and accepted for treatment.
-The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement. This includes foster homes, relative
placements and residential facilities.
-Legal parents quarterly and at reunification if the child
is a temporary court ward.
-All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is referred and accepted for treatment
One out of eight foster care records reviewed did not have
documentation that the medical health professional to whom the
child was referred and accepted for treatment signature.
REPEAT CTATION FROM 12/28/2020 INTERIM INSPECTION.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The agency appropriately cited the foster parents and developed corrective
action plans to include additional training and review of policies and procedures.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
A corrective action plan was submitted for the 12/28/2020 interim inspection report.
It appropriately addressed the following as no repeat citations are noted: personnel
records, reevaluation, license recommendation, adoption family evaluation, sibling
visitation and ongoing interaction and supervisory approval. Repeat citations include
7

the following: development of service plan, family team meeting and medical
passports.
Vll. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
Vlll. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that
Bethany Christian Service will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
